population_specificity: Adults with chronic low back pain (CLBP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility, preliminary effectiveness, and potential mechanisms of a 6-week mindfulness- and compassion-based program (MCBP) on perceived stress and psychological distress in university students.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvements in perceived stress, psychological distress, mindfulness skills, decentering, self-compassion, and experiential avoidance, while the wait-list group remained unchanged. Stress reductions were mediated by improvements in mindfulness skills, decentering, and self-compassion, while psychological distress reductions were mediated by decentering.
population_specificity: Undergraduate psychology students (n=30, 15 intervention, 15 wait-list controls).
effective_dosage: Instructor-led sessions (at least 5 attended) and formal at-home practice (4-6 days per week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mindfulness-based therapy reduces acute bipolar depression and if its effectiveness depends on baseline depression severity or therapy focus.
results_summary: The study found no evidence that mindfulness-based therapy had any effect on depression in patients with bipolar disorder. The effect sizes for therapies targeting acute depression were small and tightly clustered.
population_specificity: Adults diagnosed with Bipolar I or II disorder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of mindfulness as a complementary and alternative therapy for postpartum depression compared to standard pharmacotherapy or no treatment.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness showed efficacy in treating postpartum depression, with results comparable to or better than standard treatments in some cases, based on randomized control trials.
population_specificity: Postpartum depression patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of nonpharmacological methods, including mindfulness training, for treating negative symptoms of schizophrenia compared to other treatments or no intervention.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness training, among other nonpharmacological interventions, was effective in addressing negative symptoms of schizophrenia, as part of a broader consensus recommendation by experts.
population_specificity: Adult patients with schizophrenia, predominantly those with negative symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of mindfulness-based interventions in reducing stress and burnout among medical students compared to standard clerkship practices.
results_summary: Mindfulness-based interventions significantly reduced stress levels in medical students both immediately post-intervention and at the 6-month follow-up, with medium effect sizes and low to negligible heterogeneity.
population_specificity: Medical students

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify virtual mindfulness-based interventions for improving well-being in adults aged 19-40 in developed countries and assess their efficacy.
results_summary: Studies showed an overall improvement in well-being with mindfulness interventions, including MBSR, MBCT, and L2B programs. Modified virtual versions were found to be accessible and effective.
population_specificity: Adults aged 19-40 in developed countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a Mindfulness-Acceptance-Commitment (MAC) program could increase self-compassion and grit among elite female athletes compared to an active control condition.
results_summary: The MAC program led to greater improvements in mindfulness, self-compassion, and grit compared to the active control, with these improvements remaining stable at a four-week follow-up.
population_specificity: Elite female adult athletes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether app-based relaxation exercises, including mindfulness meditation, were more effective than usual care alone in reducing chronic neck pain.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant difference in neck pain reduction between the intervention group (using app-based relaxation exercises) and the control group (usual care) after 3 or 6 months. Adherence to the exercises was low, with only 40% of participants continuing by week 12.
population_specificity: Smartphone owners aged 18 to 65 years with chronic neck pain (>12 weeks) and baseline pain intensity ≥4 on a 0-10 scale.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clarify the role of self-compassion (SC) and evaluate potential interventions, particularly mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT), for individuals with severe mental illness (SMI).
results_summary: MBCT was the most common intervention and increased SC in SMI. The relationship between SC and depression was evident in major depressive disorder (MDD) and bipolar disorder (BD), but predictors of SC in BD and schizophrenia spectrum disorder remain unclear.
population_specificity: Individuals with severe mental illness (schizophrenia spectrum disorder, bipolar disorder, and major depressive disorder).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the efficacy and cognitive mechanisms of Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) in reducing depressive symptoms, rumination, and improving autobiographical memory in older adults.
results_summary: MBCT significantly reduced depressive symptoms, improved autobiographical memory specificity, decreased rumination, and increased mindfulness, whereas the active control group only reduced depressive symptoms.
population_specificity: 57 older adults (mean age 70) with normal cognition and mild to moderate depressive symptoms.
effective_dosage: Eight 2-hour weekly sessions and a 7-hour full-day retreat.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether framing a mindfulness intervention as focusing on a relative strength or weakness affects mood recovery and treatment expectations.
results_summary: Participants told the mindfulness intervention focused on a strength recovered more quickly from a sad mood induction, but there was no difference between the mindfulness and cognitive interventions. Framing did not affect expectations of benefit from sustained use.
population_specificity: 616 unselected undergraduates

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and acceptability of Project UPLIFT, a mindfulness-based self-management program, for patients with psychogenic nonepileptic seizures (PNES).
results_summary: The adapted UPLIFT program was successfully delivered with high attendance (98%) and completion rates; all participants found it useful for daily life, and 83% reported it helped with seizure management. Preliminary results support its potential efficacy for future trials.
population_specificity: Patients with psychogenic nonepileptic seizures (PNES).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of an internet-based ACT treatment on pain during intercourse and pain acceptance in women with provoked vulvodynia compared to no intervention.
results_summary: The treatment was efficacious in reducing pain during intercourse and improving pain acceptance, with significant differences observed post-treatment and at follow-up. However, no differences were found for tampon test measures or impact of pain on sexual function, and fewer attempts at intercourse were noted in the intervention group.
population_specificity: Women with provoked vulvodynia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether mindfulness training, combined with operant condition-based pacing strategies (Pacing+), could selectively reduce endurance behavior in adults with persistent postconcussion symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that Pacing+ (which included mindfulness training) was part of an intervention with strong treatment fidelity and participant credibility, though GET showed greater reductions in avoidance behavior. The study supported the feasibility of a future efficacy-focused trial.
population_specificity: Adults with persistent postconcussion symptoms and high avoidance or endurance behavior, enrolled at a mean of 12.9 weeks post-injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a brief mindfulness meditation program delivered via a smartphone app could improve perceived stress, self-regulation, and life satisfaction in part-time working university students.
results_summary: The mindfulness program significantly decreased perceived stress, with mindfulness and cognitive reappraisal analyzed as potential mediators. The intervention group showed positive outcomes compared to the wait-list control.
population_specificity: Part-time working university students (working at least 20 hours per week during the semester).
effective_dosage: One training session of 10-15 minutes per day using the app.

study_goal: To determine the effect of a 12-week inquiry-based stress reduction (IBSR) program on psychological well-being, sleep quality, psychosocial variables, and attitudes toward risk-reducing surgical procedures among women with BRCA variants.
results_summary: The IBSR program significantly improved psychological well-being across all measured parameters, enhanced sleep quality, and led to more favorable attitudes toward risk-reducing surgical procedures compared to standard care. These benefits were sustained at the 12-week follow-up.
population_specificity: Women in Israel carrying BRCA1 or BRCA2 germline variants.
effective_dosage: Weekly group meetings for 12 weeks (IBSR technique based on mindfulness, inquiry, and cognitive reframing).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize and analyze the knowledge map of mindfulness and meditation research from 1900 to 2021 using bibliometric tools.
results_summary: The study identified 19,752 articles, with the USA leading in global collaboration, publication numbers, and citations. Research in mindfulness and meditation has grown significantly since the first article in 1963.
population_specificity: Not specified (broad analysis of published literature)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the efficacy of psychological and non-pharmacological treatments, including mindfulness-based cognitive therapy, for reducing pain in cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness-based cognitive therapy was among the most effective interventions for reducing cancer pain, with a moderate effect size that increased at follow-up. Other interventions like music therapy and brief cognitive behavioral strategies required more research, while coping skills training and yoga did not show positive effects.
population_specificity: Adults with cancer-related pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of digitally delivered Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (Mindful Mood Balance) paired with usual depression care on reducing suicidal ideation and depression severity in patients with residual depression and a history of suicide attempts or current suicidal ideation.
results_summary: The study found that Mindful Mood Balance (MMB) was associated with a greater reduction in suicidal ideation and a higher likelihood of transitioning to a lower severity category compared to usual depression care alone. MMB also showed evidence of reducing depression severity in this at-risk group.
population_specificity: Patients with residual depression and a history of attempted suicide or current suicidal ideation (N = 109).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and effectiveness of a migraine-specific adaptation of Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) in reducing migraine-related impairment and improving psychological functioning.
results_summary: The MBCT program did not significantly reduce headache-related impairment (primary outcome) but showed a significant reduction in headache frequency and improved psychological functioning in secondary outcomes (perceived stress, anxiety, rumination, catastrophizing). Participants reported high satisfaction and achievement of personal goals.
population_specificity: 54 patients suffering from migraine
study_duration: Post-intervention assessment (timing not specified), with follow-up at 7 months

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test whether personalized or fixed anchoring strategies could improve persistent meditation routines using the Calm app.
results_summary: The fixed anchor group showed more persistent meditation, with morning anchors being particularly effective. Adherence to anchoring strategies during the intervention correlated with better persistence, though all groups experienced a decline in meditation frequency over time.
population_specificity: Predominantly White (82.2%), female (76.2%), and college-educated (81.2%) adults.
effective_dosage: At least 10 minutes of daily meditation using the Calm app.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of walking meditation versus balance training in improving balance abilities among older adults with a history of falls.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between walking meditation and balance training in improving dynamic or static balance, quality of life, or mental health. Walking meditation was deemed comparable to balance training, with good participant compliance and no serious adverse events reported.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 60-85 with a history of falls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether online mindfulness interventions are feasible and effective for improving medical students' mental health.
results_summary: The study found potential benefits in self-compassion, stress reduction, cognitive skill use, and emotional awareness, but no evidence of effectiveness for depression, anxiety, or burnout. Program usage was generally low, and participation declined near the end of interventions.
population_specificity: Medical students and residents

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize and analyze published research on the effects of mindful self-compassion interventions on stress in nurses.
results_summary: The review found that mindful self-compassion interventions had medium-to-large effect sizes for improving self-compassion, traumatic stress, burnout, stress, and compassion satisfaction, with high intervention adherence (mean=86%).
population_specificity: Nurses

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the influence of mindfulness and relaxation on essential hypertension interventions and confirm their effects on blood pressure.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that mindfulness and relaxation had minimal influence on diastolic or systolic blood pressure when used to intervene in treating cardiovascular disease and hypertension. The results were based on five studies with mixed outcomes.
population_specificity: Individuals with essential hypertension (total of 409 participants across studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility and impact of a mindfulness-based music therapy intervention on reducing anxiety and stress in adolescents and young adults (AYAs) undergoing cancer treatment.
results_summary: The intervention significantly improved perceived stress but did not show significant changes in anxiety. Satisfaction and acceptability were highly rated.
population_specificity: Adolescents and young adults (15-39 years old) receiving cancer treatment for at least eight weeks.
effective_dosage: Four sessions of individual mindfulness-based music therapy over twelve weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the integration of mindfulness, along with other wellness practices, into the holistic management of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) to improve patient outcomes beyond pharmacological treatment.
results_summary: The study suggests that incorporating mindfulness into RA management can complement pharmacological strategies, potentially improving aspects of life most impacted by RA, though specific efficacy data on mindfulness alone is not detailed.
population_specificity: People living with rheumatoid arthritis (RA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of non-pharmacologic and mindful-based approaches (e.g., relaxation, mindfulness meditation, yoga, hypnosis) for managing headache and migraine in children and adolescents.
results_summary: Non-pharmacologic and mindful-based approaches show promising safety and efficacy data for headache and migraine prevention and treatment in children, though more rigorous studies are needed to confirm these findings.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with headache and migraine disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mindfulness-based cognitive-behavioral sex therapy (MBCST) could improve sexual desire, distress, self-disclosure, and function in women with sexual desire disorder.
results_summary: The MBCST intervention significantly improved sexual desire, distress, self-disclosure, and function immediately, 4 weeks, and 12 weeks post-intervention compared to the control group (p < 0.001). The findings highlight the effectiveness of MBCST in addressing sexual dysfunction in women.
population_specificity: 70 reproductive-age women with sexual desire disorder.
study_duration: 4 weeks (with follow-ups at 4 and 12 weeks post-intervention).

study_goal: To assess the effects of mindfulness-based psychological interventions on the mental well-being and academic performance of medical students and junior doctors.
results_summary: Mindfulness interventions did not show a substantial difference in anxiety immediately post-intervention compared to waiting-list or no intervention controls. The study included 10 trials with 731 participants but did not report significant improvements in primary outcomes like anxiety and depression.
population_specificity: Medical students of any year level and junior doctors in postgraduate years one, two, or three.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of mindfulness-based stress reduction, Daily Examen, and stress inoculation training in reducing stress symptoms among clergy.
results_summary: The study measured self-reported stress symptoms and heart rate at 12 weeks, with secondary outcomes including anxiety symptoms, but specific results for mindfulness were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: United Methodist clergy in North Carolina.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to adapt and pilot a trauma-informed, mindfulness-based yoga intervention to enhance self-regulation among justice-involved youth.
results_summary: Youth participants reported satisfaction with the sessions and positive beliefs about their impact on physical and psychological/emotional challenges. Adaptations were made to ensure the intervention was contextually appropriate for justice-involved youth.
population_specificity: Youth in the Georgia Department of Juvenile Justice system (ages 14-20, 77% Non-Hispanic Black/African-American, 18% Non-Hispanic White, 5% Hispanic White).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the relationship between depression and chronic pain in a clinical trial of Integrative Medical Group Visits (IMGV) combining mindfulness techniques, integrative medicine, and group visits for income-disadvantaged patients with chronic pain and depression.
results_summary: The study found a predictive relationship between depression and chronic pain interference, mediated by high perceived stress, low pain self-efficacy, and poor sleep quality, suggesting potential targets for improving functional outcomes in chronic pain patients.
population_specificity: Diverse, income-disadvantaged patients suffering from chronic pain and depression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of pre-deployment resilience-building programs, including mindfulness-based interventions, in preventing negative mental health outcomes like PTSD in military and emergency personnel.
results_summary: Three mindfulness-based interventions successfully built resilience in their samples, but overall evidence on reducing PTSD symptoms was mixed, with no definitive conclusion on efficacy.
population_specificity: Military personnel and frontline emergency workers aged 18 or older.

study_goal: The researchers examined whether changes in mindfulness, among other behaviors and cognitions, mediated the treatment effect of a gender-tailored eHealth program on depressive symptoms in men with overweight or obesity.
results_summary: The study found no mediation effects for mindfulness in improving depressive symptoms, as measured by PHQ-9 and MDRS-22 scores, unlike other behavioral and cognitive factors.
population_specificity: Men with overweight or obesity (mean weight 103.8 kg) and current depressive symptoms (PHQ-9 ≥ 5).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mindfulness-based stress reduction could reduce the percentage of newborns born small for gestational age (SGA) and other adverse pregnancy outcomes in high-risk pregnancies.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness-based stress reduction significantly reduced the percentage of newborns with birth weight below the 10th percentile (15.6% vs. 21.9% in the control group) and improved composite adverse perinatal outcomes (19.5% vs. 26.2% in the control group). The effects were statistically significant and clinically meaningful.
population_specificity: Pregnant individuals with singleton pregnancies (19-23 weeks' gestation) at high risk for SGA, enrolled at a university hospital in Barcelona, Spain.
effective_dosage: An 8-week program consisting of weekly 2.5-hour sessions and 1 full-day session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of daily use of a mindfulness mobile application (Headspace) in improving student pharmacists' perceived stress, burnout, and mindfulness.
results_summary: The intervention group reported significantly lower stress and burnout scores and higher mindfulness scores at 6 weeks compared to the control group, with effects persisting at follow-up. Most participants continued using the app post-intervention, though usage declined.
population_specificity: Student pharmacists
effective_dosage: Daily meditation using the Headspace app

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the efficacy and mechanism of an app-delivered mindfulness training (MT) program designed to target reinforcement learning pathways in individuals with generalized anxiety disorder (GAD).
results_summary: The app-delivered MT group showed a significant reduction in anxiety (67% vs. 14% in controls) and worry, mediated by increases in mindfulness. The results suggest clinically meaningful reductions in anxiety symptoms through targeted reinforcement learning pathways.
population_specificity: Individuals with generalized anxiety disorder (GAD).
effective_dosage: 30 modules completed over 2 months (median completion: 25.5 modules).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the impact of mindfulness therapy on brain structures and processes related to PTSD, particularly its effectiveness in deactivating hindbrain regions associated with autonomic nervous system hyperarousal.
results_summary: The review found that mindfulness therapy effectively deactivates hindbrain regions involved in ANS hyperarousal, aiding trauma survivors. It also highlights mindfulness alongside EMDR and TF-CBT as beneficial for activating key brain areas like the hippocampus and prefrontal cortex, which support cognitive and affective processes in trauma recovery.
population_specificity: Individuals with PTSD (specific subpopulations not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential of Complementary and Integrative Health (CIH) approaches, including mindfulness, as alternative treatments for insomnia in military populations, particularly Veterans.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that CIH interventions like mindfulness may offer benefits for sleep disturbances in Veterans, possibly through mechanisms such as increasing hippocampal volume and GABA levels, but does not provide specific efficacy data.
population_specificity: Veterans and military populations with and without PTSD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mindfulness meditation could improve well-being among legal professionals, who experience high rates of depression, anxiety, and stress.
results_summary: Study 1 showed significant improvements in mood, resilience, trait mindfulness, stress, anxiety, and depression after an 8-week mindfulness program. Study 2 found that experimental participants had better mood, lower stress, and higher non-reactivity and observing compared to waitlist participants after a 30-day intervention.
population_specificity: Legal professionals (lawyers and other legal practitioners).
effective_dosage: Not specified (8-week program in Study 1, 30-day intervention in Study 2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of mindfulness combined with CBT compared to no treatment in managing abdominal pain in IBD patients.
results_summary: The evidence is very uncertain about the effect of mindfulness with CBT on pain intensity and frequency (MD -37.00, 95% CI -87.29 to 13.29). No treatment success or adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), including Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effects of an Integral Meditation (IM) program on psychological wellbeing and workplace functioning among non-clinical employers in an Italian service company.
results_summary: The IM program showed statistically significant improvements in mindfulness (FFMQ observing subscale), psychological wellbeing (WEMWBS), perceived stress (PSS), self-compassion (SCS), and interoception (MAIA subscales). The intervention effectively increased positive aspects of wellbeing and reduced stress.
population_specificity: Non-clinical employers from an Italian service company (n=42).
effective_dosage: 12 weekly meditation classes after the afternoon shift.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of multicomponent interventions, including mindfulness, in improving occupational health outcomes related to diet and lifestyle.
results_summary: The study found that multicomponent interventions combining mindfulness, e-coaching, and dietary changes (such as increased fruit and vegetable intake) were generally useful for combating overweight and obesity, particularly in individuals with high BMI. However, workplace environmental interventions alone did not yield expected results and were associated with increased BMI.
population_specificity: Adults (19+ years) in occupational settings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the influence of vitamin D supplementation on mental health in diabetic adults, particularly focusing on outcomes like depression, anxiety, and health-related quality of life, especially when combined with mindfulness training.
results_summary: The majority of studies confirmed the positive influence of vitamin D supplementation on mental health, particularly for anxiety and depression. For health-related quality of life, a positive effect was observed only when combined with mindfulness training.
population_specificity: Adult diabetic patients
effective_dosage: Specific doses varied; supplementation was performed for at least 12 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mindfulness-related interventions could enhance parasympathetic activity, increase vagal tone, and improve symptoms of PTSD and OCD, based on the polyvagal theory.
results_summary: Mindfulness-related interventions were found to promote parasympathetic activity, increase vagal tone, and improve PTSD and OCD symptoms, aligning with the polyvagal theory's framework for resilience and state regulation.
population_specificity: Individuals with PTSD and OCD (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a mindfulness-based intervention could reduce headache frequency in adolescents with chronic or high-frequency migraine without aura over 12 months.
results_summary: The study found that headache frequency significantly decreased from 21.3 to 9.6 days per month at 12 months, indicating a strong reduction in migraine episodes. Secondary endpoints, such as medication intake and disability, were also assessed, though specific results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Adolescents aged 12-18 with chronic or high-frequency migraine without aura.
effective_dosage: Six weekly group sessions of guided meditation and one booster session 15 days later.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify predictors of adherence and treatment outcomes in an Internet-based cognitive behavioral therapy for psychosis (ICBTp) intervention that included mindfulness as one of the topics.
results_summary: The study found that higher pre-treatment insight predicted fewer hallucinations post-treatment, and the number of completed modules was negatively associated with delusion severity. However, no variables predicted adherence to the intervention.
population_specificity: 100 participants with psychosis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential benefits of yoga and mindfulness for improving quality of life and reducing stress in children and adolescents undergoing oncological treatment.
results_summary: The reviewed studies suggest that yoga and mindfulness may improve quality of life, reduce fatigue, enhance activity levels, improve sleep, increase appetite, and decrease anxiety in pediatric oncology patients, though conclusive evidence on efficacy is lacking.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with oncological diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the impact of a school-based mindfulness intervention on bullying behaviors among teenagers.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of the mindfulness intervention on bullying behaviors.
population_specificity: Teenagers in a school setting

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) could enhance the anxiety-reducing effects of mindfulness during treadmill walking.
results_summary: The study found that active tDCS combined with mindfulness significantly reduced state anxiety one week post-intervention and decreased alpha-band EEG activity in the rostral anterior cingulate cortex (rACC), with a correlation between rACC current density changes and reduced trait anxiety in the active group.
population_specificity: 58 healthy individuals
effective_dosage: 20 minutes of active or sham tDCS

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary effects of mindfulness training (MT) on cognitive function in older individuals at risk of dementia.
results_summary: At the end of treatment, mindfulness training (MT) showed higher cognitive function scores (ZAVEN) compared to usual care (UC) and aerobic training (AT), with a similar pattern observed at a 6-month follow-up. No significant differences were found for the combined MT + AT group.
population_specificity: Older individuals (mean age 70.1 years) at risk of dementia.
study_duration: Duration of intervention not specified (follow-up at 6 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an 8-week mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) intervention in reducing stress and improving mental health, teaching outcomes, and classroom dynamics among primary school teachers.
results_summary: The study hypothesized that MBSR would reduce stress (primary outcome) and improve absenteeism, mental health, teacher skills, classroom climate, and pupil-teacher relationships (secondary outcomes), with potential mediation by self-compassion, mindfulness, and emotion regulation skills. Results were not yet reported as this is a protocol paper.
population_specificity: Dutch primary school teachers (grades 1 to 6).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Mindfulness-based intervention (MBI) could prevent excess weight gain in adolescents by reducing stress-eating through changes in executive functioning and food-reward sensitivity.
results_summary: MBI prevented worsening stress-eating compared to the health education (HE) group, which showed greater increases in stress-eating over 1.5 years. No other significant differences between conditions were observed.
population_specificity: Adolescents (12-17 years) at risk for excess weight gain (BMI ≥70th percentile or two biological parents with obesity).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a 3-day intensive Mindfulness retreat on biological mediators of stress and inflammation, as well as psychological outcomes like stress, anxiety, and awareness.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in perceived stress, anxiety, and pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-6, IL-8), along with increased awareness and anti-inflammatory IL-10 levels in Mindfulness retreat participants. Cortisol levels were highly correlated with stress and anxiety scores post-intervention.
population_specificity: 95 healthy individuals aged 18-67.
effective_dosage: Intensive 3-day residential retreat (specific daily practice duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of meditation on wellness improvement in people with cancer, medical staff, and witnesses, and to identify criteria for a subsequent randomized study.
results_summary: The study assessed adherence to the meditation program and its effects on stress, quality of life, personal effectiveness, mindfulness, empathy, and satisfaction. It also explored the added value of group meditation.
population_specificity: People with cancer, medical staff, and witnesses (non-patients/non-staff).
effective_dosage: 12 weekly meditation sessions of 1.5 hours each.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of non-pharmacological measures, including mindfulness practice, on improving mental health and immune response during the COVID-19 pandemic.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness practice, along with other non-pharmacological measures, had positive effects on mental health and immune response, contributing to better quality of life during the pandemic.
population_specificity: General population affected by the COVID-19 pandemic.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of sexual counselling educational programs, including mindfulness techniques, for improving sexual dysfunction in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: Mindfulness techniques, as part of sexual counselling programs, contributed to statistically significant improvements in sexual function, as measured by the FSFI, across multiple domains (pain, arousal, lubrication, desire, orgasm, and satisfaction). The programs were effective compared to routine care.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women aged 39-75, all in menopause for less than 5 years.
effective_dosage: Not specified (mindfulness was part of broader programs with 4-10 sessions, 45-60 minutes each).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of psychological interventions, particularly mindfulness-based interventions, for treating anxiety in pregnant women during the antenatal period.
results_summary: The review found that mindfulness-based interventions were the most effective for treating antenatal anxiety, though current guidelines do not reflect these findings. More rigorous RCTs are needed to confidently advocate for their use in practice.
population_specificity: Pregnant women with anxiety during the antenatal period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association of cognitive reactivity, rumination, self-compassion, and mindfulness with relapse in remitted MDD patients before initiating MBCT.
results_summary: Higher cognitive reactivity and lower mindfulness were associated with increased relapse risk, while self-compassion showed no association. Rumination was linked to relapse only in patients discontinuing antidepressant medication.
population_specificity: 282 remitted MDD participants with ≥3 depressive episodes, using maintenance antidepressant medication for at least 6 months.
interactions: Interaction noted with maintenance antidepressant medication (mADM) for rumination.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs) on depressive symptoms, anxiety, stress, and quality of life in family caregivers of people with dementia.
results_summary: Meta-analyses showed medium to large effects of MBIs on depressive symptoms, anxiety, stress, and quality of life immediately post-intervention, with small to large effects persisting at follow-up.
population_specificity: Family caregivers of people with dementia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary efficacy of a mindfulness-based healthy lifestyle self-management intervention for adolescents and young adults with PCOS.
results_summary: The PCOS Kind Mind Program significantly improved nutrition self-efficacy, physical activity strategies, and physical activity self-efficacy in participants. The findings suggest potential benefits of mindfulness in managing PCOS-related health behaviors.
population_specificity: Adolescents and young adults aged 14-23 diagnosed with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of respiratory therapists in diagnosing and treating post-intensive care syndrome, particularly focusing on dyspnea and pulmonary dysfunction in ICU recovery clinics.
results_summary: The study reviewed literature on respiratory therapists' roles in post-ICU follow-up, described institutional experiences, and suggested additional ways respiratory therapists could contribute to post-intensive care syndrome care. It highlighted a lack of published literature on this topic.
population_specificity: Post-ICU patients with physical, mental health, psychosocial, or cognitive dysfunction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and potential efficacy of nurse-led Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) therapy for reducing diabetes distress and improving health outcomes in people with type 2 diabetes mellitus.
results_summary: The nurse-led MBSR therapy significantly reduced diabetes distress, improved diabetes self-efficacy and self-management, and lowered HbA1c levels compared to the control group over 12 weeks. The study suggests this approach is feasible and may offer an innovative model for delivering MBSR therapy.
population_specificity: People with type 2 diabetes mellitus

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a mindfulness-based virtual reality program (Take-Pause) in reducing anxiety in pediatric emergency department patients compared to passive distraction.
results_summary: The VR group showed a significantly greater reduction in anxiety scores (10 points) compared to the iPad group (6 points), with no significant differences in pain scores or respiratory rates. No adverse effects were reported in either group.
population_specificity: Pediatric emergency department patients aged 13-17 years with acute pain.
effective_dosage: 5 minutes of VR or iPad use.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effectiveness of online mental health interventions, including mindfulness, for youth with mental health problems.
results_summary: Online mental health interventions, including mindfulness, were found effective in managing diverse mental health conditions among youth. Online self-help platforms and AI-based chatbots emerged as promising modalities.
population_specificity: Youth with mental health problems
